html:
LONDON, Feb 7 (IFR)

Contact us at IFRECM.EMEA@refinitiv.com
  • Early coverage for European IPOs
  • Abu Dhabi Ports to debut on ADX
  • Motorhome business files for Paris float

Funds managed by Warburg Pincus and Morningstar Investment are selling a 1.4% stake in Airtel Africa on Monday night. The offering of approximately 53m shares would total £82m without a discount to the 155p close. Citigroup is sole bookrunner.

There were positive signs on Monday for the IPOs of Norwegian oil and gas business Var Energi and semiconductor testing business Technoprobe with both deals now covered by investor demand.

Italy's Technoprobe opened books on Friday for a €610m–€712m Euronext Growth Milan IPO comprising 25m new shares and 88m secondary with guidance of €5.40–€6.30 per share.

Books close on February 14 for Technoprobe's IPO, which includes a 10.6% secondary greenshoe. Trading follows on February 17.

Mediobanca and Intesa Sanpaolo are joint bookrunners.

Var Energi opened books on Monday morning on an offering of 220m secondary shares from Eni and Hitec Vision at NKr28–NKr31.50 per share and garnered enough demand to cover the deal in around an hour. The price range was published on Friday so investors have had the same amount of time to decide on their orders as Technoprobe.

Books close on February 15, with trading due the following day.

DNB Markets, JP Morgan, Morgan Stanley and SpareBank 1 Markets are joint global coordinators and joint bookrunners with ABG Sundal Collier, Bank of America, Carnegie, Jefferies and Pareto Securities.

The quick coverage is significant as neither deal had cornerstones signed up at launch and there is now a full week for leads to build on that base and deliver oversubscription. They will also be trying to work out investor sensitivity through the ranges, though it is worth noting that both are quite narrow so there should be less sensitivity on the part of sellers as to where pricing comes.

Abu Dhabi  Ports has completed a Dh4bn (US$1.1bn) fundraising ahead of listing on ADX on Tuesday.

Established in 2006, ADP owns and operates 10 ports in the UAE, a terminal in Guinea, more than 550 square kilometres of industrial zones and a logistics business. The group also offers maritime services and a digital platform.

ADP contributed 13.6% of Abu Dhabi non-oil GDP in 2020, and 7.4% for the UAE as a whole.

The fundraising comprised 1.25bn shares at Dh3.20 each, representing 24.6% of the company and the state owing the balance. The market capitalisation is Dh16.3bn and proceeds will fund growth and M&A.

A note from Al Ramz Investment Research put pricing of Dh3.20 at a P/E of 20.7, a price-to-book of 1.7 and EV/Ebitda of 12.7 versus regional peers at 22.8, 4.1 and 8.8, respectively, and global peers at 17, 1.6 and 15.9.

French campervan business Hunyvers has filed a registration document for a Euronext Growth Paris IPO.

Chairman and CEO Julien Toumieux said that the leisure vehicle sector has been revived during the pandemic, with motorhomes and caravans providing freedom in the face of restrictions.

In addition to selling new and used vehicles, Hunyvers also operates CaraMaps, a website and app for travellers that has more than 620,000 users, half of which are French.

One focus is on people who went on caravan holidays in the 1980s and want to revisit them with their own children. Hunyvers said that a majority of buyers are approaching retirement or already retired, with an average age of 58 and substantial purchasing power. The company also said that 82% of motorhome owners in France are over 50.

Hunyvers said it is the second-largest player in the French market for leisure vehicles, with pro forma revenue of €91m for the year to August 31. It has a network of 15 concessions, including three boating concessions. New vehicles and spare parts sales comprise 65.3% of revenue, used vehicles 31.5%, after-sales services 3.2% and 0.1% from Caramaps.

Hunyvers has set 2025 financial targets of more than €170m in turnover, largely through organic growth, and operating profit of around 6.5% of turnover. The company has grown through acquisitions, with 11 purchases in the last 15 years.

As part of the IPO process, Hunyvers has obtained a rating of 51/100 from Ethifinance, which it said compared to average comparable companies of 33/100.

This week's deals

Monday

Abu Dhabi Ports: Dh4bn (US$1.1bn) ADX IPO, 1.25bn new at Dh3.20, 24.56% free-float, trading February 8.

Airtel Africa (UK – Telecoms): Up to £82m ABB, 53m (1.4%) secondary with reference to 155p close. Citigroup

Tuesday

ImageSat International (Israel – Satellite imagery): NIS320m–NIS480m (US$100m–$150m) Tel Aviv IPO , NIS320m primary, NIS160m, up to 37.5% free-float, no greenshoe, books January 31–February 8, pricing c. February 9, trading February 15. UBS

Thursday

Haffner Energy (France – Green hydrogen): €73m–€85m Paris Euronext Growth IPO, c. €73m primary from up to 8.34m new at €8–€9.50, up to 1.25m secondary/extension, 1.4m secondary greenshoe, 17%-23% free-float, books January 31–February 10, trading February 15. Barclays, Natixis, Portzamparc (Lazard advising)

Pipeline

February 14 – Polenergia (Poland – Energy)

Z1bn (US$245m) follow-on, 21.4m new shares at up to Z47. Shareholders January 31–February 4, subs open February 10–14, allocations February 17. Ipopema Securities

February 14 – Civitanavi Systems (Italy – Sensors)

€43.65m–€50.4m Milan IPO, 9.7m shares (7.2m new, 2.5m secondary) at €4–€5.20, 1.455m greenshoe, 30.1%–34.6% free-float, books February 2–14, trading February 17. Berenberg, Intermonte

February 15 – Var Energi (Norway – Oil & gas) COVERED 07/02

NKr6.16bn–NKr6.93bn (US$704m–$793m) Oslo IPO, 220m all-secondary at NKr28–NKr31.50, potential 55m upsize, 33m share greenshoe, 8.8%–12.7% free-float, books February 7–15, pricing/trading February 16. DNB Markets, JP Morgan, Morgan Stanley, SpareBank 1 Markets, ABG Sundal Collier, Bank of America, Carnegie, Jefferies, Pareto Securities

c. February 18 – Technoprobe ( Italy – Semiconductor testing equipment) COVERED 07/02

€610m–€712m  Euronext Growth Milan IPO, 25m new, 88m secondary at €5.40–€6.30, 12m/10.6% secondary greenshoe, 18.8%–20.8% free-float, books February 4 to c. February 18. Intesa Sanpaolo, Mediobanca

Early February – Clean Power Hydrogen (UK – Hydrogen technology)

£50m AIM IPO. Cenkos

Early February – LXi REIT (UK)

£125m placing, 3-for-25 open offer, offer for subscription and intermediaries offer, 88.62m (12%) new at 142p (2.9% premium to estimated NAV of 139.5p, 6.8% discount to 152.4p January 17 close), books open c. January 24, close early February. Alvarium Securities, Jefferies, Peel Hunt

Late February – GCP Co-Living REIT (UK)

£300m LSE IPO, 300m new at 100p, closes before end February. Stifel Nicolaus Europe (Akur advising)

Early March – Fred Olsen Windcarriers (Norway – Wind turbines)

c. €150m-equivalent Oslo IPO, all-primary, books c. February 17–March 3. Arctic Securities, DNB Markets, SpareBank 1 Markets

March – Oxford Biomedica (UK – Biotech)

£80m firm placing, offer for subscription, EGM mid-February. Peel Hunt, WG Partners
